[Header]

Bonham Texas.
Nov 28 – /88.

My dear Professor:
I am glad to acknowledge
the receipt of your excellent letter.
Your hearty "endorsation" of the Govs
"Texas" enhances my appreciation of
that most excellent & timely contribution
to our Southern literature.
A wicked & exacting press have
intimated that the publication under
consideration classes with the Common
Almanacs of the day – Such injustice!
It is enough "To stir a fever in the
blood of age and make infant
sinews strong as steel". If ever
I get to be Gov & find myself in
position to say "Come & he cometh – go
& he goeth"! I shall order a fearful
reckoning for those wicked paper
men. There was an oracle at
Delphi – Now Texas has hers & it must
not be spoken against

[Footer]

(over)

[Header]
Austin Texas
Nov 23 - 83
[Margin: Dr Wagener]

I would like to see you occupy a
Chair in the University & if I can serve
you, you have but to command me.
One of the Regents being [illegible] applicant
for a Chair, I fear, would give him
a decided advantage. This is my
judgment in the matter. I may
apply for the Chair of Latin or Greek in
the University if deemed advisable to
do so. What do you think of it?
I have been unable to see the Report
of the Regents – I see reference made
to it in the papers, as well as in
your letter. If you have it will
you send it to me. My name
was presented to the Houston Board
when the late Superintendent was
elected – I would be glad to
exchange my present position
for the one made vacant in Houston

[Header]

[1881, Nov. 28]

but I can not apply for the place.
I feel sure that H. H. Smith will
be the man. The leading spirit in
the Houston Board is an earnest
Episcopalian – so is Smith.
Besides, I think Smith gave general
satisfaction during his first Superintendency
& is now "out in the cold" – with nothing
to do – but to look after a place.
But a few weeks ago he was corresponding
with a view of coming to Chappell Hill.
That project failed.
For some days past I have been
almost sick from cold.
Our friend Moore was quite sick –
is better to-day – the same genial
noble man – Write soon.

[Signature]

Your friend
J. T. Hand
